The effect of continents on gravity is more complicated than the video suggests.  Yes, the mass of the continents protruding above sea level does attract the oceans towards it, but the rock making up the continental plates is on average less dense than the rock of the mantle in general.  The continental plates 'float' in the denser mantle like ice in water, with the majority of their mass extending down deep into the mantle.  So the influence of the continents is a mixture of stronger and weaker gravity.

It's extremely unlikely that this list of 100 ones and zeroes is random.

For any given random list of binary states with n elements, there is very likely going to be a run of the same state consecutively, of size log[base 2](n) or greater (round down). For example, in a random list of 32 ones and zeroes, there's likely to be a spot where you see 5 ones or 5 zeros. In a list of 100, you'd expect a run of 6, but the longest run is 4.

Of course, it's still possible that it was randomly generated. That's the thing about randomness; you can never really know.

I'd say that the zeros and ones are not a random sequence. I did an analysis of the microstates (before spending 10 minutes doing this I did the obvious and checked if it translated into anything interesting from ascii to no avail) for combinations of one, two three, and four number fragments. In a random generation, there would be roughly equal occurrences for each microstate, give or take because of the small sample size, but in the above sequence there was no semblance of uniformity between microstates, especially when analyzing the larger sequence fragments the apparent randomness faded away as three or four of the 16 microstates (2^4) were used most of the time. It's still amazing, though, because even if the sequence were made by "randomly" pressing one and zero on a keyboard, it's not a truly random sequence, and I think that says something about the human mind and it's tendencies towards patterns, to the point that it inadvertently can create them, because all that science really is (at a very basic level) is the search for patterns in the world around us. I could rant on for a while about the fallibility of those tendencies, like how people always seem to forget that correlation isn't causation because patterns always feel so right to us, but let's just marvel at the complexity of our own minds instead.

The 1's and 0's are more flip-floppy than they should be if random.  The value stays the same (00 or 11) 38 times, and flips (01 or 10) 61 times.  A random string of 1's and 0's would only be this flip-floppy about 2% of the time (including more extreme results of flip-floppiness or streakiness).  We humans tend to prefer flip-flops when looking for randomness because we see long strings of the same value as non-random.  We could do other analyses of features like the average streak length, and I think we would reach similar conclusions.

Long-story short. Not random.
There is a >>>99%chance you would not get a string with so few or so many twins, triplets, quads and quintuplets.
I calculate P<0.000001. Yes, 1 in 1 million.

Hmmm 53 1s and 47 zeroes, that is good. There is a 61.7% chance of that or worse happening randomly, but a 51.6% chance that it will be that close or less.
every character should have a 50/50 chance of being followed by the same character except for the last, for which we will use the first as the character following it.
there are only 38 characters followed by themselves. This seems heavily biased and not random, considering that it is over 2 standard deviations from the mean. There is only a 2.1% chance it would either be so blinky or unblinky.
Of the characters following themselves, half should be followed, again by themselves. In this bitstring, only 10 are out of 38. This is extremely unlikely. there is a 99.5% chance that a random string would have between 11 and 27.
What about, of these, half should should be, again, followed by the same digit. There are 4 cases out of 10 where that happens, which is fine since there would only be a 24.6% chance of exactly 5 happening that way.
What about 5-strings of the same digit? There is an 87.5% chance after all that a 5-string should occur from 4 four-strings.
Overall. This shows a distribution that tends to prefer alternating digits. This could indicate that it encodes some kind of meaningful information on periodic basis.
For example, using TRUE RANDOM numbers that are generated by small-scale turbulence in the atmosphere, etc, I get strings of repeating digits at least 5-long every time in a 96-digit generator. I even get 9-digit strings of repeating digits occasionally and 7-digit ones most of the time.
With 100 digits, the odds of not getting a single quintuplet are exceedingly low, only 0.15% if wrap-around is allowed. A random distribution would average about 50 twins instead of 38, 25 triplets instead of 10, 12.5 quadruplets instead of 4, and 6.25 quintuplets instead of none, 3.125 sextuplets instead of none, 1.5625 septuplets instead of none.... etc.

So I claim that you either generated hundreds of random numbers and picked the "most-random" one, made a generator with the Gambler's fallacy hardcoded in, or that the information means something specific.

The Free Fact is ambiguous or misleading. An oblate spheroid is just an older term for an ellipsoid of revolution, where the revolution is around the minor axis. Since an ellipsoid (not a triaxial ellipsoid) has only two principal axes, if they are the same, it's a sphere. When they differ and the ellipsoid has been developed by revolving it around the minor axis, then it's an oblate ellipsoid. If the rotation was around the major axis, it would be a prolate ellipsoid.
Conventionally, we use an oblate ellipsoid of revolution in geodesy to represent the model of the Earth, and it has just two principal axes. Therefore sections parallel to the equatorial plane are circles, while sections parallel to the axis of rotation are ellipses. A triaxial ellipsoid does give a slightly better fit, but it's a pig to do the computations!
The model of the global geoid (what is colloquially termed Mean Sea Level, but actually isn't, really) is based on a spherical harmonics modeling of the overall shape. While it's tied to WGS 84, it's not part of it as such. To correct for the geoid-elipsoid separation globally, a positioning system needs to include the appropriate model if the geoid.
Within the confines of time and space, this video is a good explanation. But there are PhDs in geodesy because it's not quite that simple!

the list of 0's and 1's are not random. Assuming there is an equal chance of getting a 0 or a 1, true randomness would have a lot of streaks of over 6, 0's or 1's in a row (test it out by flipping a head 25-50 times. It is highly probable that you get either a 5-chain or 6-chain of heads or tails.
In this end pattern at 3:09 there is no chain longer than 4 in a row, which is very fishy and signals the human uneasiness of writing another 0 or 1 because they feel that randomness must "correct" itself to make the probability around 50% of each 0 and 1.
However, this is wrong because each digit is equally likely, and of the 4 times that there was a repeat of 4 digits, 2 of them should have been 5 digits long, and 2 should be 4 digits long based on the 50% probability. The chance that none of these 4 went on to be 5 chains is 1/16 or around 6.25%. 
Also there are 18 (i think i counted right) chains of 2 0's and 1's in a row, and only 8 chains of more than 2. Considering that each of these chains of greater than 2 were at one point only a chain of two tells us that only 8/26 chains of the original 2-chains made it to a chain bigger than 2, which is less than 33%, no where near the 50% that randomness should have it be.
Basically, this list is clearly the result of a human, it shows how we feel uneasy to see a chain of 0's or 1's because we think that randomness makes it so that they should balance out, and force it to balance by cutting chains off prematurely.

In answer to your question "Can you tell whether or not it's random?", the answer is no. If I were to randomly generate 100 ones and zeros, I could obtain any of the following:

11111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111
11111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111111

00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000
00000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000000

01010101010101010101010101010101010101010101010101
01010101010101010101010101010101010101010101010101

These appear, for all intents and purposes, to be ordered series, and yet they would still be randomly-generated strings.

I'm going to take a stab at explaining why I think the numbers aren't random. In the 100 numbers, I found 4 strings of 4 of the same number (that's four 0's or four 1's in a row) but no strings of five. If a string of four has already been generated, there is a 50% probability that it will continue to a string of 5 and a 50% probability it will end with the next number. The probability that four strings of four generated will all end with the next number would be .5^4 or 6.25%. Long story short, with 100 numbers, I'd expect to see at least one string of five. I could be totally wrong though, as my math wasn't very thorough.

@MinutePhysics 

You can determine if the given sequence is random by using the fact that for a random sequence, all subsequences of a specific length should occur with equal probability.

Let us initially assume it is equally likely that the sequence is random vs non-random (i.e. - our prior probability of the sequence being random is 0.5).

Now, looking at single digit occurrence, we see that there are 46 0's and 54 1's in the sequence. The probability of observing this given that the sequence is random is approximately 0.057958 (obtained using a binomial distribution).

The probability of observing 46 0's and 54 1's in all cases is the probability of observing it if the sequence is random (times the probability the sequence is random), plus the probability of observing it if it isn't random (times the probability the sequence isn't random).

If the sequence isn't random, lets assume all occurrences are equally likely. I.E. - 46 0's and 54 1's is as equally likely as 2 0's and 98 1's. This is actually equivalent to 54 0's and 46 1's, so there is symmetry and we're looking for 2x, where x is the probability of a single outcome. We see that there are clearly only 100 of these, so 2 * 1/100 = 0.02. So the probability of observing 46 0's and 54 1's in all cases is 0.057958*0.5 + 0.02*0.5 = 0.038979.

Given all this information, we can use Bayes' theorem to work out that the updated (posterior) probability of the sequence being random given the observation of single digit occurrence is about 0.74345.

We can do this with all the other digit sequences of specified length. I.E. - We should expect 00 and 10 to occur with the same frequency. Same thing for 01 and 11. Continue this method for all groupings up to N digits using the posterior probability of randomness from the previous calculation for the new prior probability of randomness for the next calculation, and you will have a maximally informed estimate of the randomness of the sequence.

I did this method by hand up to N = 3. At that point I arrived at a probability of 23.855% that the sequence was random. So probably not random. Again, a better estimate can be obtained by using more clusters.

What does it even mean to say that some definite number or digit sequence is random? Is 9 random? 34? 90? It doesn't really make sense (to me, at least), to claim, for instance, that 90 is a random number. Of course, like any other number, it can be drawn from a probability distribution of some sort, but it's the distribution that's random, not the number. To be fair, though, for the digit sequence at the end of this video, it's reasonable to believe you could somehow find the probability that the digits were drawn from a uniform distribution, given that they were chosen independently. But that's only one reasonable definition of what it would mean for the sequence to be truly random.

Are these numbers a random sequence?
What is a random sequence of alternating values?
A random sequence of alternating values is a sequence where there is zero predictability. The probability for each successive value in the sequence has a 50% probability to be different from its predecessor and a 50% probability to be the same value.

How often will continious streaks of successive values occur? Cut this imaginary random string in sequences of the same value. Each sequence has a length of 1 value (the first value, 1 or 0 is a given).

* The probability that the second value in the sequences is equal to the first: 50%, the rest are all the sequences with length 1, the remaining 50%. The sequences with a lenght longer than 1 represent 1/2.

* The probability that the third value is the same as the first (and second) as well: 50% of the sequences of length longer than 1, so 50% of 1/2 that are left, i.e. 1/4. The rest are all the sequences with length 2, the remaining 25%. The sequences with a lenght longer than 2 represent 1/4.

* The probability that the third value is the same as the first (and second, and third) as well: 50% of the sequences of length longer than 2, so 50% of 1/4 that are left, i.e. 1/8. The rest are all the sequences with length 3, the remaining 12.5%. The sequences with a lenght longer than 3 represent 1/8.

etc...

So:
Expected distribution of sequences:
Length        Probability
1                 50%
2                 25%
3                 12.5%
4 and more 12.5%

In this string:
Length Observed Expected
1                  36       31.0
2                  18       15.5
3                    4         7.8
4 and more:   4         7.8

A Chitest in Excel should calculate the probability if having these observed frequencies, given the hypothesis that this is a random string. No Excel present, but I expect the probability to be higher than any credible significance level.
